Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is preparing to try a new skateboard trick on a steep, uneven ramp.
Situation2: The partner received disappointing feedback at work and is visibly upset.
Story: I stood at the edge of the skate park, my heart pounding as I watched my younger brother adjust his helmet, determined to try a new trick on the steep, cracked ramp. He caught my eye and grinned, but I could see the nervousness in his hands. I knew I should be right there, ready to stop him if things went wrong, to make sure he didn’t get hurt. But my phone buzzed again—another message from Alex, my boyfriend. He’d had a rough day at work, his boss tearing apart a project he’d poured his heart into. He needed me, needed someone to listen, to reassure him that he wasn’t a failure. I could almost hear his voice trembling through the screen. I felt torn in two, my brother’s safety on one side, Alex’s pain on the other. Both expected me to be there, to care, to help. My chest tightened as I tried to decide where I was needed most, feeling the weight of letting someone down no matter what I chose.
